snippet: Israel and Palestinian militants resumed cross-border air assaults after a three-day cease-fire expired, but the renewed violence seemed less about meeting military goals than about jockeying for leverage in talks that had made little progress.
abstract: Fighting resumes between Israel and Palestinian militants in Gaza strip after expiration of three-day cease-fire; new attacks seem more about gaining leverage in stalled talks than actual completion of military goals.

byline.original: By JODI RUDOREN and ISABEL KERSHNER
byline.contributor: Jodi Rudoren reported from Gaza, and Isabel Kershner from Jerusalem. Merna Thomas and Kareem Fahim contributed reporting from Cairo, Somini Sengupta from the United Nations, and Fares Akram from Gaza.

lead_paragraph: Israel and Palestinian militants resumed cross-border air assaults after a three-day cease-fire expired, but the renewed violence seemed less about meeting military goals than about jockeying for leverage in talks that had made little progress.

headline.main: New Fighting a Bid for Leverage as a Gaza Cease-Fire Expires
headline.print_headline: New Fighting a Bid for Leverage as a Gaza Cease-Fire Expires
